item.content:encoded:
Africa Needs AI Built by Africans – Applications Open for Phase 1

Applications are now open for the UniPods AI Solutions for Africa Program, a 12-month pan-African initiative designed to equip university students with practical artificial intelligence (AI) skills and support them in developing, prototyping, and launching impactful AI-powered solutions for Africa.

The program combines foundational training, advanced product development, incubation, and market launch support — giving participants a full pathway from learning AI to building real-world solutions.

What is the UniPods AI Solutions for Africa Program?

The UniPods AI Solutions for Africa Program is a multi-stage learning and innovation journey that helps students transition from AI beginners to solution builders.

The program focuses on:

  • Practical AI and data science skills

  • Building solutions that address African challenges

  • Product development and innovation

  • Entrepreneurship and market readiness

Participants progress through structured phases that move from training to implementation.

Program Structure – 4 Phases

Phase 1: Online Foundational AI Skilling

Participants gain core AI skills through a certified online program delivered in collaboration with the University of Tokyo (GCI World course).

This phase covers:

  • Data science foundations

  • Python programming

  • Machine learning fundamentals

  • Practical business applications of data

This phase serves as the entry point into the program.

Phase 2: Advanced Hybrid Training & Product Development

Participants advance their technical skills while beginning to design and build real AI solutions with UniPod support.

Key focus areas include:

  • Applied AI development

  • Problem-solving for African contexts

  • Product prototyping

  • Team collaboration

Phase 3: In-Person Incubation Residency

Selected participants join an intensive residency at the Addis Ababa AI UniPod, where they refine their solutions with mentorship and technical guidance.

Phase 4: Market Take-Off

Participants test, refine, and prepare their AI solutions for launch with continued UniPod support.

This phase emphasizes:

  • Market readiness

  • Solution validation

  • Scaling strategies

Who Should Apply?

The program is designed for:

  • University students across Africa

  • Beginners interested in AI and data science

  • Students passionate about solving African challenges through technology

  • Aspiring AI innovators and entrepreneurs

No advanced programming experience is required to start Phase 1.

Why This Program Matters

Africa’s digital future depends on locally built solutions. This initiative aims to empower young African innovators to:

  • Build AI solutions relevant to African realities

  • Gain globally recognized technical skills

  • Work on real-world innovation projects

  • Move from learning to launching impactful products

Phase 1 – Foundational AI Training (University of Tokyo)

The first phase is delivered online through the Global Consumer Intelligence (GCI World) course developed by the Matsuo-Iwasawa Lab at the University of Tokyo.

Participants will learn:

  • Introduction to data science

  • Data cleaning and visualization

  • Machine learning concepts

  • SQL and feature engineering

  • Time series analysis

  • Real-world data applications

The course includes weekly lectures, assignments, competitions, and final projects.

Program Benefits

Participants will gain:

  • Certified foundational AI training

  • Practical hands-on experience

  • Access to mentorship and incubation

  • Opportunity to develop real AI products

  • Potential pathway to launch solutions in African markets

Important Deadline

Phase 1 Application Deadline: March 2, 2026

Early application is strongly recommended.

How to Apply

Interested students can register for Phase 1 (Foundational AI Skilling) through the official application portal.

Applicants will be guided through:

  1. Email registration

  2. Platform ID creation

  3. Verification of student status

  4. Enrollment in the GCI World course

Final Thoughts

The UniPods AI Solutions for Africa Program is more than an online course — it is a complete innovation pathway designed to help African students move from learning AI to building real solutions that address local challenges.

If you are a student passionate about technology, innovation, and Africa’s future, this is a strong opportunity to begin your AI journey. Interested students can register for Phase 1 (Foundational AI Skilling) through the official application portal.

item.content:encoded:
TaRL Africa is expanding its leadership team in Nigeria and is now hiring a Country Regional Manager (Programs) to drive regional scale, government partnership, and high-quality implementation of the Teaching at the Right Level (TaRL) approach.

If you are an experienced program leader with a strong background in education systems reform, government engagement, and multi-state program management, this is an opportunity to lead transformative change at scale.

Position: Country Regional Manager, Programs

Location: Kaduna, Nigeria

Reports to: Country Director, TaRL Africa Nigeria

About TaRL Africa

TaRL Africa is hosted by Empower Learning Africa, a not-for-profit organization headquartered in Nairobi, Kenya, with teams across Côte d’Ivoire, Nigeria, and Zambia. The initiative was launched in 2019 as a joint venture between Pratham and J- PAL.

TaRL Africa partners with governments and organizations across more than 15 Sub-Saharan African countries to accelerate children’s foundational skill acquisition using the evidence-based Teaching at the Right Level methodology. Together with partners, the initiative has reached over five million children.

Our vision is for every child across Africa to have strong foundational skills that unlock lifelong opportunity.

About the Role: Country Regional Manager (CRM)

The Country Regional Manager (CRM) will lead and expand TaRL programming within a defined region in Nigeria. This role oversees implementation across multiple states, manages regional teams, strengthens partnerships with state governments, and ensures program delivery with fidelity, scale, and sustainability.

As a key member of the Country Management Team, you will shape regional strategy, drive operational excellence, oversee budgets, and lead continuous program improvement.

This position requires extensive travel within the region and occasional travel across Nigeria and Africa.

Key Responsibilities

1. Program Leadership & Partnership Management (40%)

  • Strengthen technical implementation of the Teaching at the Right Level model.
  • Ensure high-quality program delivery through data-informed decision-making.
  • Provide oversight to state teams to maintain financial health and operational efficiency.
  • Guide annual planning cycles and conduct periodic program reviews.
  • Build strong, productive relationships with government stakeholders and community partners.
  • Drive contextual program design aligned with regional needs.

2. Regional Strategy & Scale (30%)

  • Identify and execute strategic expansion opportunities across states.
  • Promote government ownership and long-term sustainability.
  • Translate regional priorities into coordinated work plans and budgets.
  • Use needs assessments, stakeholder insights, and program data to refine strategy.

3. Strengthening the TaRL Ecosystem (15%)

  • Improve operational tools, systems, and accountability frameworks.
  • Lead special innovation projects in collaboration with Programme Design, Pedagogy, and Monitoring, Learning & Evaluation teams.
  • Contribute to cross-state learning and organizational knowledge sharing.

4. Team Leadership & Performance Management (15%)

  • Build, mentor, and manage high-performing regional teams.
  • Set clear performance goals and monitor progress.
  • Foster accountability, ownership, and continuous professional development.
  • Cultivate a collaborative and impact-driven team culture.

Who We Are Looking For

We are seeking a results-oriented leader with:

  • Proven experience managing medium to large-scale education or development programs
  • Strong stakeholder engagement experience with governments and donors
  • Demonstrated ability to lead multi-state implementation
  • Strategic planning and expansion expertise
  • Budget oversight and financial management capability
  • Strong analytical and data-driven decision-making skills
  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills

Minimum Qualifications

  • Bachelor’s degree in Public Policy, International Development, Education, or related field (Master’s degree such as MPA or MPP preferred).
  • At least six (6) years of experience managing medium to large-scale programs.
  • Experience working with donors, policymakers, researchers, and government agencies.
  • Strong proficiency in Excel, Word, PowerPoint, and Google Suite.
  • Excellent communication skills.

Why Join TaRL Africa?

This is more than a job. It is a leadership opportunity to shape foundational learning outcomes for millions of children across Nigeria.

You will:

  • Influence education reform at scale
  • Strengthen government systems for sustainable impact
  • Lead high-performing teams across multiple states
  • Contribute to a growing, mission-driven organization operating across Africa
  • Play a key role in evidence-based education transformation

If you are ready to lead with purpose and deliver measurable impact, we encourage you to apply.

Application Deadline: 3rd March 2026

 

APPLY HERE

For more opportunities on jobs ,click here .

item.content:encoded:
Are you looking for a paid European Union traineeship that offers real experience inside EU institutions? The Consilium Traineeship Programme at the Council of the European Union provides young professionals with the opportunity to work directly with EU policy experts, gain institutional experience, and contribute to high-level decision-making processes.

Applications are now open for the upcoming traineeship cycle — a highly competitive programme designed for ambitious graduates interested in European affairs, governance, law, policy, and international cooperation.

What Are Consilium Traineeships?

The Consilium traineeship programme offers first-hand exposure to how the Council of the European Union and its General Secretariat operate.

The name Consilium comes from the Latin word meaning counsel or deliberation, reflecting the Council’s role in shaping EU decisions and supporting member states in policy coordination.

As a trainee, you will:

  • Gain practical experience within EU institutions

  • Work alongside experienced advisors and policy professionals

  • Contribute to the Council’s daily activities

  • Develop professional skills in an international environment

  • Build networks across European institutions

The programme is ideal for graduates interested in EU governance, policy-making, international relations, law, public administration, or related fields.

Traineeships are paid and include allowances and other benefits. Around 110 traineeship positions are available each year.

  • Your traineeship: tasks, grants, allowances

Paid Traineeship Benefits

The Consilium traineeships are fully paid and include financial support designed to help trainees live and work in Brussels.

Key benefits include:

  • Paid monthly grant

  • Additional allowances and benefits

  • Professional training and mentoring

  • Exposure to real EU policy work

  • International multicultural working environment

Approximately 110 traineeship positions are offered each year, making it one of the most attractive EU traineeship opportunities for early-career professionals.

Current Application Window (2026 Cycle)

Applications are currently open for the next traineeship term.

Important dates:

  • Application deadline: 19 March 2026 (12:00 Brussels time)

  • Traineeship period: 1 September 2026 – 31 January 2027

  • Location: Brussels, Belgium

Applicants are encouraged to submit early to avoid last-minute technical issues.

APPLY HERE

Positive Action Programme for Trainees with Disabilities

The Council reserves up to six traineeships per year for EU nationals with a recognised disability.

This programme ensures inclusive participation by offering:

  • Equal access to EU policy experience

  • Special workplace arrangements when required

  • Supportive and accessible working conditions

Participants gain the same high-quality exposure to EU decision-making while benefiting from tailored accommodations.

  • Apply for the positive action programme 
  • Positive action programme for trainees with a disability

Who Can Apply?

Consilium traineeships are open to EU citizens who meet specific eligibility criteria outlined by the Council.

The programme targets:

  • Young graduates and early-career professionals

  • Candidates interested in EU affairs and policy

  • Individuals seeking professional experience within EU institutions

Applicants should review the official eligibility criteria before applying.

Who can apply for a traineeship

How to Apply for a Council Traineeship

The application process is designed to be straightforward and fully online.

Application steps:

  • Check eligibility requirements

  • Prepare required documents

  • Complete the online application form

  • Submit before the deadline

The same procedure applies to both:

  • Main traineeship programme

  • Positive action programme for trainees with disabilities

Applications are only open during specific periods each year, so timing is important.

How to apply for a traineeship

Online Information Session

To help candidates better understand the programme, the Council is hosting an online information session.

Details:

  • Date: 9 March 2026

  • Time: 14:00–15:00 (Brussels time)

  • Format: Online presentation + Q&A

  • Registration: No prior registration required

This session is highly recommended for applicants who want insider guidance on the application process.

No prior registration needed.

  • Follow our info session about Consilium traineeships 

Consilium Traineeship Calendar

The Council offers traineeships twice per year.

February – June Traineeship

  • Applications: August – September

  • Selection & interviews: October – December

  • Traineeship period: 1 February – 30 June

September – January Traineeship

  • Applications: February – March

  • Selection & interviews: April – June

  • Traineeship period: 1 September – 31 January

Understanding the cycle helps candidates plan applications well in advance.

Traineeships for Students of National Administration Schools

In addition to the general programme, the Council also offers specialised traineeships for students enrolled in national administration schools.

Key features:

  • Duration: 2 to 5 months

  • Focus on EU processes and institutional policy

  • Designed to strengthen administrative and governance expertise

Frequently Asked Questions

Candidates can consult the official FAQ section for detailed guidance on:

  • Eligibility requirements

  • Application documents

  • Selection process

  • Working conditions

  • Financial support

Reviewing the FAQ before applying can help strengthen your application.

More questions? Check our FAQ to find the answers to most recurrent questions.

  • Traineeships: frequently asked questions

Why Apply for a Consilium Traineeship?

A traineeship at the Council of the European Union offers more than work experience — it provides direct exposure to the heart of European policy-making.

Key reasons to apply:

  • Gain practical EU institutional experience

  • Build an international professional network

  • Strengthen your CV for careers in policy, diplomacy, or development

  • Work in Brussels, one of Europe’s key political hubs

  • Learn how EU decisions are shaped in real time

For young professionals aiming to build a career in European or international affairs, this programme is a powerful stepping stone.

Final Tip for Applicants

Strong applications clearly demonstrate:

  • Interest in EU affairs

  • Relevant academic or professional background

  • Motivation to contribute to European policy work

  • Ability to work in multicultural environments

Prepare your documents early and submit before the deadline to maximise your chances.

APPLY HERE

Source : European Council

item.content:encoded:
Applications are now open for the AFAS Master’s Fellowships 2026 intake, offering fully funded opportunities for young African scholars to pursue advanced studies focused on Nature-based Solutions (NbS), climate change adaptation, and biodiversity conservation across African savanna landscapes.

This highly competitive programme is designed for motivated graduates who want to bridge science, policy, and practice and contribute to real-world environmental solutions across Africa.

  • Application deadline: 31st March 2026
  • Applicants may apply to either the University of Nairobi (UoN), Nairobi, Kenya, or Université Félix Houphouët-Boigny (UFHB), Abidjan, Côte d’Ivoire, BUT NOT BOTH
  • There is a simultaneous call for master fellowships at CABES, a project closely linked to AFAS. Applicants can only apply to either the CABES or AFAS master programme BUT NOT BOTH

About the AFAS Master’s Programme

The African Climate and Environment Centre – Future African Savannas (AFAS) is a part of the Global Centers for Climate and Environment program of the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD). AFAS is a partnership of four universities: the University of Nairobi (UoN), Université Félix Houphouët-Boigny (UFHB), the University of Cologne, and the University of Bonn. The program is based at the University of Nairobi through its Institute for Climate Change and Adaptation (ICCA) in Nairobi, Kenya, and at the Université Félix Houphouët-Boigny through its African Centre of Excellence on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Agriculture (CEA-CCBAD) in Abidjan, Côte d’Ivoire.

The African Climate and Environment Centre – Future African Savannas (AFAS) is part of the DAAD Global Centers for Climate and Environment Programme. AFAS brings together a consortium of leading institutions:

  • University of Nairobi (Kenya)

  • Université Félix Houphouët-Boigny (Côte d’Ivoire)

  • University of Cologne (Germany)

  • University of Bonn (Germany)

The programme is hosted at:

  • Institute for Climate Change and Adaptation (ICCA) – University of Nairobi

  • African Centre of Excellence on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Agriculture (CEA-CCBAD) – UFHB

AFAS trains graduates to connect research with policy and practice while engaging directly with stakeholders, communities, NGOs, and decision-makers.

Programme Focus Areas

AFAS Phase 2 (2026–2030) builds on earlier success and emphasizes implementation, stakeholder engagement, and real-world impact. The programme focuses on:

  • Nature-based Solutions (NbS)

  • Science–Policy–Practice Interface (SPPI)

  • Climate change adaptation

  • Ecosystem conservation in African savannas

For their Master’s thesis, fellows will select one primary thematic area:

  • Water

  • Agriculture

  • Energy

  • One Health

  • Biodiversity

Applicants must explain their thematic preference in their motivation and reflection statement.

Fellowship Overview (2026 Intake)

AFAS will award 18 fully funded Master’s fellowships across its two host universities.

Selected fellows will:

  • Enroll in an AFAS-aligned Master’s programme

  • Participate in joint courses and hybrid modules

  • Receive soft-skills training

  • Conduct demand-oriented research on Nature-based Solutions

  • Engage with policy actors and practitioners

  • Complete a Master’s thesis linked to real-world challenges

Language of instruction: English

What the Fellowship Covers

The AFAS fellowship provides comprehensive support, including:

  • Full tuition fees

  • Monthly stipend (local currency equivalent)

  • Health insurance

  • Laptop computer

  • Individual research budget (after proposal approval)

  • Participation in summer schools, workshops, and exchange activities

Funding continuation depends on satisfactory academic progress and engagement.

Who Should Apply

This is not a conventional academic scholarship. AFAS seeks applicants who demonstrate:

  • Critical and independent thinking

  • Strong motivation and reflection

  • Ability to connect environmental challenges with practical solutions

  • Clear personal insight and contextual understanding

Applications that rely on generic or scripted responses may be disadvantaged.

Selection Process

Selection is competitive and conducted in multiple stages:

  1. Eligibility screening

  2. Qualitative review of motivation statements

  3. Shortlisted interviews assessing reasoning and alignment with AFAS

  4. Final selection (subject to admission at host university)

Host University Options

Applicants may apply to ONE host institution only.

1. University of Nairobi (UoN), Kenya

Candidates willing to apply must have:

  • Concluded a Bachelor’s or equivalent degree in environmental and/or agricultural sciences or biology, ecology and climate sciences, economics, sociology, or any other relevant discipline.
  • Must have a minimum second-upper honors degree or equivalent approved by Kenya’s Commission for University Education (CUE)
  • Must not be older than 26 years on the 2nd of October 2026.
  • Must be willing to be a single/individual resident in the student’s residence recommended by the University of Nairobi for the duration of the program.
  • This is a fulltime assignment which requires physical presence and outside work is not permitted for the duration of the fellowship.
  • Applicants from universities which do not use English as a language of instruction should provide evidence of English proficiency in the form of a certificate of IELTS or TOEFL or equivalent demonstrating a satisfactory level of competence.
  • University Certified Diplomas/Bachelors/Masters certificates (if not in English, please provide official English translation from/or certified by the university). Note: In certain cases, further verification may be required from Kenya’s Commission for University Education (see below).
  • Before applying for the scholarship, applicants are expected to visit the University of Nairobi website https://www.uonbi.ac.ke and the Department of Earth and Climate Sciences website http://earthclimatesciences.uonbi.ac.ke to confirm their eligibility for admission and get more details on the program, respectively.
  • At UoN, selected candidates will immediately be required to seek admission to the University of Nairobi master’s program in Climate Change Adaptation through the University website https://application.uonbi.ac.ke/. An application fee (approximately USD 50) will be charged which is non-refundable.
  • A passport is required for non-Kenyan citizens.

2. Université Félix Houphouët-Boigny (UFHB), Côte d’Ivoire

Eligibility Highlights:

  • Concluded a Bachelor’s or equivalent degree in environmental and/or agricultural sciences or biology, ecology and climate sciences, economics, sociology, or any other relevant discipline.
  • The required university degrees must have been awarded by a university or a higher education institution officially recognized by the African and Malagasy Council for Higher Education (CAMES).
  • Must not be older than age 26 years on the 2nd of October 2026.
  • Be willing to be a single/individual resident on the campus of “Pôle Scientifique et d’Innovation de l’UFHB” for the full duration of the program.
  • This is a full-time assignment which requires physical presence and outside work is not permitted for the duration of the fellowship.
  • UFHB applicants from Central and Western Africa are encouraged to apply.
  • University Certified Diplomas/Bachelors/Masters certificates. All certified documents not issued in French must be accompanied by an official French translation.
  • Applicants from French-language academic backgrounds are asked to provide official evidence of English language proficiency, in the form of an IELTS or TOEFL certificate or equivalent demonstrating a satisfactory level of competence.
  • A passport is required for non-citizens of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS).

Required Application Documents (Single PDF Submission)

Motivation & Reflection Statement (max. 1000 words, 1.5 space, 11 Calibri)                                                                                                    

Applicants must respond explicitly to the following prompts:

      • Which ONE of the five thematic areas would you like to do research on: water, agriculture, energy, One Health and biodiversity? Motivate your choice with a short research idea in max. 250 words?
      • Which other ONE of the five thematic areas could also be of interest to you (one sentence; no motivation needed)?
      • What concrete environmental or development challenge motivates you personally?
      • How do you understand Nature‑based Solutions in your own context?
      • Describe one real example (project, policy, community practice, or observation) that shaped your interest.
      • How do you see yourself engaging with policy or practice actors, not only actors from academia?
      • What skills or perspectives do you hope to develop during AFAS Phase 2?
    2. Curriculum Vitae (max. 2 pages)
    3. University Certified Diplomas/Bachelors/Masters certificates (see details above).
    4. University Certified Transcripts of academic records (see details above).
    5. Two duly signed letters of recommendation, including the full contact details of the referees (at least one of the letters must be issued by a member of staff of the institution that awarded the most recent degree).
    6. Proof of English proficiency (if applicable)
    7. Birth certificate
    8. A recent passport photo

Motivation & Reflection Statement Prompts

Applicants must address:

  • Preferred thematic research area and short research idea (max. 250 words)

  • Secondary thematic interest

  • Personal environmental or development motivation

  • Understanding of Nature-based Solutions in context

  • Real-life example influencing interest

  • Engagement with policy or practice actors

  • Skills and perspectives to develop during AFAS Phase 2

Important Application Notes

  • Applicants may apply to either AFAS or CABES, not both.

  • Applicants may apply to either UoN or UFHB, not both.

  • Only shortlisted candidates will be contacted for interviews.

For technical questions, contact: info@afas.africa

Why This Opportunity Matters

The AFAS Master’s Fellowship is ideal for young professionals and graduates interested in:

  • Climate change adaptation in Africa

  • Biodiversity conservation

  • Nature-based Solutions research

  • Environmental policy and practice

  • Sustainable development careers

By combining academic excellence with practical engagement, AFAS prepares future leaders to address complex environmental challenges across African savannas.

How to Apply

Applications are open now for the 2026–2028 intake.

APPLY HERE 

FOR MORE INFORMATION PLEASE CLICK HERE

Deadline: 31 March 2026

Interested applicants should prepare their documents early and submit a strong, reflective application demonstrating real-world understanding and motivation.

item.content:encoded:
The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) Internship Program offers a unique opportunity for students and recent graduates to gain hands-on experience in international development, finance, research, policy, and innovation. Through paid internships at IDB, IDB Invest, and IDB Lab, participants work alongside global experts and contribute to projects that improve lives across Latin America, the Caribbean, Asia, and Europe.

If you are looking to launch your international career with a respected multilateral organization, this guide explains everything you need to know — from eligibility requirements to application tips.

Why Choose the IDB Internship Program?

The IDB internship program is designed to help students and young professionals:

  • Gain practical experience in international development

  • Work on real projects with global impact

  • Build professional networks across regions

  • Learn about development finance and policy

  • Experience the organizational culture of the IDB Group

Interns work directly with teams at IDB Headquarters in Washington, D.C., or in country offices worldwide, with occasional teleworking flexibility depending on the role.

Types of Internship Opportunities

1. Internships at IDB Headquarters (Washington, D.C.)

Interns at headquarters support teams delivering operational and corporate solutions to public and private sector clients.

Program Structure

  • Duration: 2 months

  • Work schedule: Full-time (40 hours per week)

  • Format: On-site with some flexibility

Internship Cycles

  • Winter Internship: January 16 – March 15

  • Summer Internship: June 16 – August 15

Applications typically open 3–4 months in advance.

Important Note:
Applicants may apply for a maximum of three internship positions.

2. Internships at Country Offices (COFs)

The IDB has offices across Latin America and the Caribbean, as well as Asia and Europe. These internships are designed to strengthen local development capacity while helping interns build careers in their own regions.

Key Features

  • Duration: 2 to 6 months (based on business needs)

  • No fixed cohort timeline

  • Continuous recruitment throughout the year

Eligibility Requirement
You must be:

  • A citizen or legal resident of the country where the office is located, or

  • Hold a valid work permit and reside in that country.

Fields of Study in Demand

The IDB welcomes students from diverse academic backgrounds, including:

  • Business and Finance

  • Communications and Marketing

  • Data and Technology

  • Economics and Research

  • Environmental Studies

  • Humanities and Social Sciences

  • Law and Policy

  • Linguistic Services

Basic Eligibility Requirements

To qualify for the IDB Internship Program, applicants must meet the following criteria:

Citizenship

  • Washington, D.C. internships: Must be a citizen of one of IDB’s 48 member countries

  • Country Office internships: Must be a citizen or legal resident of the country where applying

  • IDB Invest roles: No citizenship restrictions

Academic Status

  • Active undergraduate student (minimum second year), or

  • Graduate student with at least 50% of coursework completed

Availability

  • Must be available to work full-time (40 hours per week)

Additional Requirements

  • Must not have relatives working at IDB, IDB Invest, or IDB Lab

  • Internship must be your first job within the IDB Group

Required Documents

Applicants must prepare the following documents:

  • Updated Resume (CV)

  • University Enrollment Letter (issued within the last 3 months)

  • Academic Transcripts (official or unofficial; issued within the last 3 months)

Note: If you advance in the recruitment process, official transcripts may be required.

How to Apply for IDB Internships

Step 1: Online Application

Complete the application form and upload your CV in English or Spanish. A cover letter is only required if specified in the job posting.

Pro Tips

  • Read the job description carefully

  • Tailor your CV to match the role

  • Keep your resume concise and results-focused

Step 2: Assessment & Interview

If shortlisted, you may be invited to:

  • Complete a technical assessment

  • Attend a formal panel interview with IDB staff

Pro Tips

  • Follow instructions carefully during assessments

  • Practice interview responses beforehand

  • Be clear, authentic, and concise in your answers

Step 3: Final Decision

Recruitment timelines may vary. The IDB provides estimated timelines and applicants can follow up with HR for updates.

If you are not selected, you are encouraged to apply again as new positions open regularly.

Visa Information for International Applicants

For internships at headquarters in Washington, D.C., the IDB supports eligible candidates with G4 Visa processing.

Key points:

  • Available to non-U.S. citizens and non-permanent residents

  • Eligible dependents may also receive G4 visas

  • Dependents may apply for U.S. work authorization

  • Employees must live within 50 miles of headquarters

Visa approval remains at the discretion of the U.S. Department of State.

What It’s Like to Be an IDB Intern

Interns often highlight:

  • Exposure to international development projects

  • Networking with global teams

  • Opportunities to contribute to regional impact

  • Professional growth and career clarity

Many interns describe the program as a stepping stone into careers in international organizations, development finance, and policy.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

How long does the application process take?
The process may take several weeks or months depending on the role.

Do I need a cover letter?
Only if requested in the specific job posting.

Does the IDB hire globally?
Yes. The IDB recruits for headquarters and country offices worldwide.

Are there eligibility restrictions?
Yes. Citizenship requirements apply for most positions, except some roles at IDB Invest.

The IDB Internship Program is a strong opportunity for students and recent graduates who want to build careers in international development, economics, finance, and public policy. With paid placements, global exposure, and meaningful project work, the program provides a solid foundation for future leadership in development.

If you are serious about building a global career, prepare your documents early, tailor your CV carefully, and apply strategically.

Apply & Learn More

For full program details and available internship opportunities, visit the official IDB careers platform and explore open positions regularly.

For a detailed list of available positions and Application, click HERE.

Apply Now

Don’t miss this opportunity to gain hands-on experience in international development. Visit our official website to submit your application before the deadline.

For further inquiries or accommodations, contact us at diversity@iadb.org.

item.content:encoded:
Application Deadline: Friday, March 20, 2026

Applications are now open for the 2026 MILEAD Fellows Program, a leadership development initiative designed to support and empower young African women leaders committed to driving positive change across the continent.

For over a decade, the MILEAD Fellows Program has equipped emerging leaders with the knowledge, skills, and networks needed to challenge inequality, advance women’s leadership, and implement community-driven solutions.

About the MILEAD Fellows Program

The MILEAD (Moremi Initiative Leadership and Empowerment Development) Fellows Program is a long-term leadership development initiative focused on identifying and nurturing promising young African women leaders.

The program aims to:

  • Build leadership capacity among young African women

  • Strengthen knowledge, skills, and values for 21st-century leadership

  • Create a supportive ecosystem for women’s leadership across Africa

  • Connect emerging leaders with influential African mentors and changemakers

Each year, 25 outstanding young women are selected based on their leadership potential and commitment to making a difference in their communities or professional fields.

Program Structure and Key Features

The program combines leadership training, mentoring, experiential learning, and community engagement.

Key components include:

  • A three-week residential Summer Institute in Ghana

  • Intensive leadership and personal development training

  • Mentorship from established African leaders

  • Access to the MILEAD leadership network

  • Ongoing support and lifelong peer solidarity

A distinguishing feature of the program is the MiCHANGE Community Project, where each fellow designs and leads a community-based initiative addressing issues affecting women and girls.

Eligibility Criteria

Applicants should meet the following requirements:

  • Be a young African woman aged 19–25

  • Demonstrate leadership potential or experience

  • Show commitment to addressing issues affecting women and girls in Africa

  • Be interested in developing transformational leadership skills

  • Be available to participate in the three-week residential Summer Institute in Ghana

Selected candidates may be full-time students or professionals during the program, except during the residential institute period.

Application Requirements

Applicants must submit:

  • Completed application form

  • Updated CV

  • Two recommendation letters

All application materials must be submitted via email.

Email: Fellows@moremiinitiative.org

Applicants are strongly encouraged to carefully review the program and application guidelines before submitting.

Application Resources

Download the full 2026 Application Package (Application Pack |  Recommendation-Form), and share this opportunity with other inspiring emerging African women leaders in your network.

Stay updated: follow us @MoremiAfrica #MILEADFellows #MILEAD2026

EMAIL: Fellows@moremiinitiative.org | TEL: +233 530 429 644

 

Why Apply?

The MILEAD Fellows Program is designed to build a pipeline of African women leaders equipped to drive systemic change. Fellows benefit from:

  • High-quality leadership training

  • Practical experience through community projects

  • Exposure to experienced African leaders and mentors

  • A lifelong network of women leaders across Africa

The program emphasizes long-term impact by integrating leadership development with real-world community engagement.

Contact and Updates

For more information:

  • Website: www.moremiinitiative.org

  • Facebook: /MoremiAfrica

  • Twitter/X: @MoremiAfrica

  • Email: Fellows@moremiinitiative.org

  • Tel: +233 530 429 644

The 2026 MILEAD Fellows Program offers an important opportunity for young African women who are ready to strengthen their leadership skills and contribute meaningfully to social change across the continent.

Interested candidates should submit their applications before March 20, 2026.

Find out more https://moremiinitiative.org/2026-milead-fellows-program-announcement/

item.content:encoded:
The Empowerment of Young Women Farmers in Africa through Inclusive Mentorship Programme (EYPA) is officially launching Phase II, marking a major step forward in supporting young women in agriculture across Africa.

Building on the success of its pilot phase, the programme is being implemented through a renewed partnership between the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the Pan-African Farmers’ Organization (PAFO). This new phase places a strong focus on young women farmers, aiming to strengthen leadership, entrepreneurship, and economic opportunities within Africa’s agrifood systems.

What is EYPA Phase II?

The  first phase of the EYPA Programme‘s Mentorship Programme is designed to provide inclusive mentorship, capacity building, and professional networking opportunities for young women working in agriculture.

Phase II will scale up the successful mentorship model developed during the pilot stage by addressing gender-specific challenges that often limit women’s participation and leadership in agrifood systems.

Through this initiative, participants will gain:

  • Tailored mentorship from experienced professionals

  • Capacity-building activities and training sessions

  • Networking opportunities across regions

  • Skills development for agribusiness growth

  • Increased confidence and leadership capacity

The programme also supports the goals of   the International Year of the Woman Farmer (IYWF 2026) by promoting women’s economic empowerment and closing gender gaps in agriculture.

Call for Expression of Interest Now Open

A Call for Expression of Interest has been launched to recruit both mentors and mentees for the programme.

Application Deadline: Friday, 6 March 2026

Find the call for mentees here

Find the call for mentors here 

Up to 50 young women farmers from different regions across Africa will be selected to participate in this phase.

What Participants Will Gain

EYPA Phase II aims to unlock the potential of young women leaders and innovators by equipping them with practical and business-focused skills, including:

  • Financial literacy and business planning

  • Organizational and leadership skills

  • Market access and value chain understanding

  • Agribusiness development strategies

  • Professional mentorship and peer learning

By strengthening these competencies, the programme contributes to the broader transformation of Africa’s agrifood systems and supports sustainable economic growth.

Regional Pitching Sessions and Final Competition

Following the structure of the pilot phase, the mentorship journey will culminate in regional pitching sessions where mentees will present their agribusiness ideas and business models.

Participants will showcase:

  • Business and financial models

  • Innovation and sustainability approaches

  • Social and economic impact of their ventures

Finalists demonstrating strong pitching skills will advance to a final pitching competition hosted at the PAFO Headquarters in Kigali, Rwanda.

During the final event, selected mentees will:

  • Present their agribusiness progress

  • Showcase outcomes from the mentorship journey

  • Compete for two cash prizes

Strengthening Youth and Women Leadership in Agriculture

The EYPA Mentorship Programme reflects the shared commitment of FAO and PAFO to building youth leadership and empowering women in agriculture.

Implemented under a broader Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) collaboration, Phase II represents a strategic effort to equip young women farmers with the tools, knowledge, and opportunities needed to thrive in modern agrifood systems.

By investing in mentorship and capacity development, EYPA aims to nurture the next generation of agricultural leaders driving innovation and sustainability across Africa.

The launch of EYPA Phase II signals a powerful opportunity for young women farmers to strengthen their skills, grow their agribusinesses, and expand their professional networks.

For aspiring women leaders in agriculture, this programme offers a unique platform to learn, connect, and showcase innovation on a continental stage.

item.content:encoded:
The European Forum Alpbach Scholarship Programme 2026 is now open for applications, offering a fully funded opportunity for students, young professionals, and emerging leaders from around the world to participate in one of Europe’s most prestigious interdisciplinary forums. Held annually in the Austrian Alps, the European Forum Alpbach (EFA) brings together future changemakers, policymakers, researchers, and innovators to exchange ideas, build leadership skills, and shape solutions for Europe and the world.

This scholarship programme is designed for first-time participants who want to gain international exposure, expand their networks, and engage in high-level dialogue across sectors.

About the European Forum Alpbach Scholarship Programme

Every year, hundreds of young talents travel to Alpbach to take part in a unique two-week experience that combines academic learning, policy dialogue, and cross-cultural exchange. Scholarship holders are at the heart of the Forum and are the only participants who remain for the full duration of the event.

The programme includes:

  • Scientific, competence-based, and artistic seminars and studios

  • High-level conferences with global decision-makers and experts

  • Leadership and skills development sessions

  • Interdisciplinary discussions and networking opportunities

  • Social and cultural activities designed to foster collaboration

Approximately 350 scholarships are awarded annually by the European Forum Alpbach and the Forum Alpbach Network (FAN).

Application Dates for EFA Scholarship 2026

Applicants should take note of the official application period:

  • Applications open: 2 March 2026

  • Application deadline: 22 March 2026 (11:59 PM CET)

Due to the competitive nature of the programme, early preparation is strongly recommended.

Why Apply for the European Forum Alpbach Scholarship?

The EFA Scholarship Programme offers more than financial support. It provides an immersive leadership experience that helps participants grow professionally and personally while engaging with some of the most pressing issues facing Europe and the world.

Key benefits include:

  • Full participation in the European Forum Alpbach event

  • Access to influential policymakers, academics, and industry leaders

  • International networking with peers from diverse backgrounds

  • Opportunities for leadership development and interdisciplinary learning

  • Long-term connection to a global alumni community

EFA as a Lifelong Community

Participation in the European Forum Alpbach does not end after the event. Scholarship holders become part of the Forum Alpbach Network (FAN), a strong international alumni community dedicated to promoting dialogue and cooperation across borders.

The network includes:

  • 34 alumni initiatives

  • Representation across 20 countries

  • Year-round events and collaboration opportunities

  • A growing community committed to shaping a better Europe

How to Apply for the EFA Scholarship Programme

Applicants can submit their applications through two pathways depending on their regional affiliation.

Applications will be open from 2-22 March 2026

(2 pm – 11:59 pm CET)

Application via the Forum Alpbach Network (FAN)

Applicants with nationality or residency ties to specific FAN clubs must apply through their respective alumni club.

FAN clubs with separate scholarship selection processes include:

These are the FAN clubs who offer EFA-scholarships and have a separate selection process: CA Burgenland, CA Liechtenstein, CA Niederösterreich, CA Poland, CA Upper Austria, CA Salzburg, CA Senza Confini (Carinthia, Northern Italy and Slovenia), CA Steiermark, CA Südtirol Alto Adige, CA Tirol, CA Vorarlberg, IG Wien.

Applicants should consult the relevant FAN club website for detailed requirements and deadlines.

Application via the European Forum Alpbach (EFA)

If there is no FAN club in your country, or your local club does not have its own selection process, you may apply directly via the EFA online application platform.

Important application rules:

  • The scholarship is open to international applicants worldwide, with a special focus on Europe outside Austria

  • Applications must be submitted through the official online portal

  • Incomplete applications will not be accepted

  • Applications submitted by email will not be considered

  • Missing documents submitted after the deadline will not be reviewed

Special note: Nationals or permanent residents of ROC Taiwan must apply via the Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation.

Documents Required for the Application

Applicants should prepare all required documents before beginning the application process. Ensuring completeness and accuracy is essential, as incomplete applications may be automatically rejected.

Disqualification Policy and Use of AI

The organisers clearly state that applications may be disqualified if:

  • Minimum eligibility criteria are not met

  • The letter of motivation is generated using artificial intelligence

Applicants are encouraged to submit authentic and original application materials.

Q&A Webinars for Applicants

To support prospective applicants, the organisers are hosting official Q&A webinars where participants can speak directly with the scholarship team.

Webinar schedule:

  • Do you still have questions?

Sign up for one of our Q&A webinars on the EFA26 scholarship programme and talk directly to the organisers.

Webinar #1

Thursday, 26 February 2026 5:30 pm – 6:30 pm (CET). Register here.

Webinar #2

Wednesday, 4 March 2026 5:30 pm – 6:30 pm (CET). Register here. 

Webinar #3

Tuesday, 17 March 2026 9:30 am – 10:30 am (CET). Register here. 

Contact Information

For additional questions about the scholarship programme:

  • Email: scholarships@alpbach.org

  • Contact person: Melissa Német, Unit Communities, Stakeholder Manager, Scholarship Programme

Who Should Apply?

The European Forum Alpbach Scholarship Programme is ideal for:

  • Students and recent graduates

  • Young professionals and early-career leaders

  • Researchers and policy enthusiasts

  • Social impact practitioners and civic leaders

  • Youth changemakers interested in global dialogue and European affairs

Applications will be open from 2-22 March 2026

(2 pm – 11:59 pm CET)

The European Forum Alpbach Scholarship Programme 2026 is a highly competitive, fully funded opportunity for young leaders seeking international exposure, meaningful dialogue, and long-term professional growth. With access to influential networks, interdisciplinary learning, and a vibrant alumni community, the programme offers a powerful platform for those ready to contribute to shaping the future of Europe and beyond.

item.title: LinkedIn Future of Work Fund 2026: Global AI Workforce Grant Supporting Nonprofits Preparing Young Adults for the AI Economy
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Mensah
item.description:
The LinkedIn Future of Work Fund 2026 is a global philanthropic grant initiative designed to help nonprofit organizations prepare young people for a rapidly changing labor market shaped by artificial intelligence. As automation and AI technologies continue transforming industries, LinkedIn is expanding its commitment to economic inclusion by funding organizations that help young adults successfully […]

item.content:encoded:
The LinkedIn Future of Work Fund 2026 is a global philanthropic grant initiative designed to help nonprofit organizations prepare young people for a rapidly changing labor market shaped by artificial intelligence. As automation and AI technologies continue transforming industries, LinkedIn is expanding its commitment to economic inclusion by funding organizations that help young adults successfully transition into an AI-powered workforce.

The 2026 edition builds on LinkedIn’s first year of funding nonprofit innovators worldwide and introduces an expanded funding round combining financial grants and in-kind support resources. The program focuses specifically on young adults facing structural barriers to employment and aims to ensure that technological transformation does not widen inequality.

Why the Future of Work Fund Matters

Artificial intelligence is not just creating new jobs; it is reshaping nearly every existing one. According to LinkedIn projections, approximately 70% of the skills required for jobs will change by 2030. This means traditional career preparation models are becoming outdated.

The challenge is not simply training people to use technology. Instead, the workforce now requires a combination of:

  • AI fluency and digital capability

  • Critical thinking and adaptability

  • Communication and collaboration

  • Problem-solving in uncertain environments

Many young adults — particularly those from underserved backgrounds — lack access to training and opportunities that help them adapt to this shift. The Future of Work Fund exists to support organizations solving exactly this problem.

What the Fund Supports

The fund provides both financial grants and in-kind support to nonprofit organizations delivering programs that expand economic opportunity in an AI-driven labor market.

Key Focus Areas

Organizations applying must demonstrate a clear and practical approach to at least one of the following:

1. Preparing Young Adults for AI-Driven Careers

Programs that teach AI literacy, digital skills, and workforce readiness for modern job markets.

2. Improving Job Access

Initiatives helping career starters connect with employment opportunities using technology and AI-enabled pathways.

3. Supporting Workforce Success

Training that helps young workers thrive after employment through adaptability, communication, and lifelong learning skills.

4. System-Level Workforce Innovation

Projects influencing how education systems, training institutions, or employers integrate AI workforce preparation.

What LinkedIn Means by “AI Innovation”

LinkedIn is not only interested in teaching technical coding skills. Instead, the fund prioritizes organizations that combine technological learning with human capabilities.

Supported initiatives typically include:

  • AI-fluency training programs

  • Career navigation tools powered by AI

  • Skills-matching platforms

  • Job readiness pathways

  • Human-skill development (communication, collaboration, adaptability)

  • Alternative credential programs

Who the Fund Aims to Help

The program focuses on young adults entering the workforce who face employment barriers.

These may include:

  • Individuals from low-income communities

  • First-generation professionals

  • Learners outside traditional university pathways

  • Underemployed youth

  • Career starters without professional networks

Typical target age range: 18–24 (varies by country)

Eligibility Requirements for Organizations

To qualify, applicants must meet all of the following conditions.

Organizational Status

  • Must be a legally registered nonprofit, charity, or equivalent not-for-profit organization

  • U.S. organizations must hold 501(c)(3) status

  • Must be able to directly receive grant funding

Program Focus

Organizations must demonstrate:

  • Workforce development programming

  • Clear use of AI innovation OR preparation for AI workforce transition

  • Support for young adults facing economic opportunity barriers

Organizations not meeting these requirements are encouraged to use LinkedIn’s free nonprofit resources instead.

Funding and Support Structure

Selected organizations receive a combination of monetary and strategic assistance.

Financial Support

Cash grant funding for program implementation and expansion.

In-Kind Support

  • Access to LinkedIn expertise

  • Workforce insights and data

  • Platform resources

  • Strategic guidance

This hybrid model helps organizations scale impact beyond traditional grants.

Evaluation Criteria

Applications are reviewed based on:

  • Demonstrated impact potential

  • Clarity of AI integration

  • Capacity to support underserved young adults

  • Scalability of program model

  • Alignment with economic inclusion goals

Application Deadline

March 15, 2026 at 12 PM PT

Submit your application HERE.

Visit the LinkedIn Social Impact website HERE for more details.

Click HERE to discover more grant opportunities.

item.content:encoded:
The Mercy Corps Strengthening Caribbean Economic Growth (SCEG) Program has launched a Small Grants Challenge aimed at supporting organizations driving sustainable economic development across the Caribbean.

Through this funding opportunity, up to 12 organizations will receive grants of up to $50,000 USD each to implement impactful, locally driven projects that strengthen livelihoods, businesses, and economic systems in the region.

About the SCEG Small Grants Challenge

The SCEG initiative is designed to accelerate inclusive economic growth by empowering organisations working to:

  • Expand employment opportunities across key sectors

  • Strengthen micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs)

  • Improve access to market-driven inputs, services, and business support systems

This program prioritizes practical, scalable solutions that can create measurable economic impact within a 12-month project period.

Why Apply?

This grant offers a powerful opportunity to:

  • Access funding to scale your economic impact

  • Strengthen local business ecosystems and employment

  • Partner with an internationally recognized development organization

  • Deliver measurable results that support long-term economic resilience

Who Can Apply?

This opportunity is open to registered organisations that are based in or operating within the following Caribbean countries:

  • Barbados

  • The Bahamas

  • Grenada

  • Jamaica

  • Saint Kitts and Nevis

Organisations may include NGOs, social enterprises, private sector actors, and development-focused institutions that align with the program’s goals.

Grant Value and Duration

  • Grant amount: Up to $50,000 USD per organisation

  • Number of awards: Up to 12 grantees

  • Project duration: Maximum of 12 months

Key Dates

  • Application Open: February 9, 2026

  • Application Deadline: February 23, 2026 (11:59 PM AST)

 How to Apply

Interested organisations can submit their applications HERE

Opportunity Summary

Category Details
Program Name Strengthening Caribbean Economic Growth (SCEG) Small Grants Challenge
Host Organization Mercy Corps
Location Caribbean (Barbados, Bahamas, Grenada, Jamaica, Saint Kitts & Nevis)
Funding Amount Up to $50,000 USD
Deadline February 23, 2026
Project Duration Up to 12 months

If your organisation is working to create jobs, support MSMEs, or strengthen economic systems in the Caribbean, this is a strong opportunity to secure funding and scale your impact.

Apply before the deadline and position your organization at the forefront of economic transformation in the Caribbean.
